### One Stage Object Detectors

#### YOLO

<img src="https://blog.kakaocdn.net/dn/blwCUo/btqCOgkRa9Y/uB2fUlB6LyGzCTtXYh22DK/img.jpg">

- Recall sliding window object detection
- To make it efficient, we will "slide our window" only on certain locations of the image
- We devide our image in a grid
- Place a box at the center of each cell in the grid, and this will be our initial box guess for that object
- Direct regression from image to box coordinates (image -> CNN -> Detection)
- In YOLOv2, we use anchor boxes(feature map of 7 * 7 * C, for each grid location we predict n boxes) image -> 7 * 7 * C . To very similar with RPN, image -> 7 * 7 * C -> 3 * 3 convolution -> 7 * 7 * (25 * n) -> Detection

#### SSD: Single Shot multibox Detector

<img src="https://blog.kakaocdn.net/dn/bcij4N/btqA9ALo331/ENUWrzcqtqyTIUQ9FV6OCK/img.png">

- SSD is to reduce the size of feature map
- Using anchor box
- Input image size is fixed (300 * 300 or 512 * 512)
- Each feature map has each classifier
- To train the information of anchor box, 3 * 3 convolution for each feature map
- Pros: very fast, end-to-end trainable and fully convolutional, SSD detects more objects than YOLO
- Cons: Performance is not as good as two-stage detectors, difficulty with small objects

#### Problem with one-stage detectors
<li> Two-stage detectors

- Classification only work on "interesting" foreground regions. Most background examples are already filtered out
- Class balance between foreground and background objects is manageable
- Classifier can concentrate on analyzing proposals with rich information content

<li> One-stage detectors
- Many locations need to be analyzed densely converting the image -> foreground-background imbalance
- Hard negative mining is useful, but not sufficient

#### RetinaNet

It can solve the anchor of foreground-background imbalance

-Focal loss

<img src="https://images.velog.io/images/skhim520/post/ee768e89-77d3-4139-8014-af654f3ada4d/image.png">

- When r = 0, it is equivalent to the cross-entropy loss
- As r goes towards 1, the easy examples are down-weighted
- The goal of Focal Loss is down-weighted for easy example, and more weighted to hard example. Because in the many cases, there are so many easy examples(background). So, if we use the focal loss, we can detect objects efficiently. 

### One-stage (point-based) detectors

#### CornerNet

- Express bounding boxes with 2 points, the top-left and bottom-right corners

<img src="https://blog.kakaocdn.net/dn/c3gaNt/btq4dK68kHL/vqYy6XV6uJixH5i4keMBM1/img.png">

<img src="https://velog.velcdn.com/images%2Friverdeer%2Fpost%2F79789063-ac75-40f9-8160-c3413dd874a9%2Fimage.png">

- One of the head of Heatmaps is for top-left corner and the other one is for right-bottom corner, and it indicates the possibility to find the corner in several positions of the feature map. Therefore, heatmaps is probability map for each corner type
- Embeddings: Box identification with an embedding (needed to match top and bottom keypoints)

<img src="https://miro.medium.com/max/1080/1*64PUWScdjXJeE3m30HS2hg.png">

- We predict corners at a lower resolution and then regress an offset

<li> Corner Pooling

<img src="https://production-media.paperswithcode.com/methods/Screen_Shot_2020-06-23_at_1.06.25_PM.png">

- "Corner pooling" is used to combine the information from the predicted two corners to represent the extent or range of an object.

#### Problem with CornerNet

- Many incorrect bounding boxes(especially small) -> too many False Positives
- Hypothesis: It is hard to infer the class of the box if the network is focused on the boundaries

#### Solution

- idea: focus on the center of the object to infer its class
- Use the corners as proposals, and the center to verify the calss of the object and filter out outliers

<img src="https://blog.kakaocdn.net/dn/MiovJ/btq4sqAR8TJ/hLb94MOK7klMfHaFMCHgJ1/img.png">

- To improve the classification of the object, and predict accurate location of the object

#### ExtremeNet

<img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/xingyizhou/ExtremeNet/master/readme/teaser.png">

- No need to predict embedding for the box computation
- We can predict where is the peak through heatmaps. 
- Extract the peaks
- Center Heatmaps
- Combine with each peaks, and if it matches the center, we can get high center score. And if not, it is low center score, and then reject

#### Detection evaluation

- TP(True positive): bounding box indicates the object
- FP(False positive): bounding box doesn't indicates the object
- FN(False Negative): There is an object in the image, but bounding box doesn't predict the object

<li> Precision: how accurate your predictions are

- Precision = $\frac {TP} {TP + FP}$

<li> Recall: how good you are at finding all positives

- Recall = $\frac {TP} {TP + FN}$

##### What is the positive?

- We use the Intersedtion over Union(IoU) or Jaccard Index
- If IoU > 0.5 -> positive match
- Depending on the database it is 0.5 or 0.7

#### AP

- Mean Average Precision(mAP)

- For each image and class independently, rank the predicted boxes by confidence score. Assign the boxes to the coreesponding ground truth if IoU > 0.5 
- Each ground truth box(location and size) can only be matched to one predicted box
- For each class independently, compute Average Precision(the area of precision-Recall-graph)
- Mean over all classes to obtain mAP 

#### Recall non-maximum suppression

- Classification ground truth: We compute ${p^*}$ which indicates how much an anchor overlaps with the ground truth bounding boxes
- ${p^*}$ = 1 if IoU > 0.7
- ${p^*}$ = 0 if IoU < 0.3
- 1 indicates the anchor represent an object(foreground) and 0 indicates background object. The rest do not contribute to the training

#### NMS

case for 3 objects

- Many bounding boxes are predicted by the CNN
- Most confident region remains
- Second most confident region remains
- Third most confident region remains
- Other all overlaped boxes are removed
- If there is a box which does not overlap with ground truth boxes, we will keep it

Problem with highly overlapping objects

- with an NMS threshold of o.4, we remove both boxes(IoU = 0.49, 0.5), hence we have a False Negative 
- With an NMS threshold of 0.6, we keep box boxes(IoU = 0.49, 0.5), hence we have a False Positive

#### Detection beyond 2D boxes

Predictin "as points"

- 3D bounding boxes: prediction of the center + orientation + width + height + depth
- Facial landmarks
<img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/9bUgR.png">

- Human pose estimation: body joint

#### Human pose estimation

<img src="data:image/jpeg;base64," width=500>

- Estimate a 2D pose (x,y) coordinates for each joint from a RGB image
- Parameterization:
  - 17 joints
  - left/right ankle
  - left/right knee
  - etc
- It is challenging: clothing, extreme poses, viewpoint changes
- Approach 1: direct regression
    - image -> CNN -> Feature map -> body joints
- Approach 2: heatmap prediction
  - Instead of prediction by regression, for each joint one predicts a full image with a heatmap of the joint location

<img src="data:image/jpeg;base64,">

- Ground truth(GT) heatmap is constructed by placing a 2D Gaussian around the joint position
- Loss: MSE(Mean squared Error) between predicted and GT heatmap
- Bringing the structure of the problem
  - Body parts are linked to each other
  - Bidy symmetries
  - Joint limits(elbow cannot bend backwards)
  - Pysical connectly: elbow connected to wrist
- can solve the limits by using graphical models
- Using graphycal models also allows us to find the pose of several targets
  1. All joint detection as provided directly by the CNN
  2. Cluster the joints based on joint type and target ID
  3. Final prediction
- Object detection + Pose estimation
- Improving the architecture: Stacked hourglass
    - Repeated bottom-up(high to low res) and top-down processing (low to high res)
<img src="data:image/png;base64,">

#### Hourglass -Unet -Autoencoder

<li> Architecture that first scales down the resolution and then upsamples it to get to the initial resolution

<img src="data:image/jpeg;base64,">

- Encoder: down sampling to get small size feature map
- Encoder: normal convolutional filters + pooling
- Decoder: up sampling(pooling) + convolutional filters
- The convolutional filters in the decoder are learned using backprop and their goal is to refine the upsampling

#### Upsampling in hourglass

<li> Interpolation

<img src="https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcTE_E9K25g4gz1r_s9Or8DjoLDPJoaYUrQ-vIwJQYpu1aDshzJxkf8tv98fTY4Rh_LXLlQ&usqp=CAU" width= 400> nearest neighbor interpolation

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width=400>
Bilinear interpolation

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width=400>
bicubic interpolation

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width=400>

#### Residual connections

- improving the architecture: Stacked hourglass
- Preserve spatial knowledge at each resolution

<img src="https://production-media.paperswithcode.com/methods/Screen_Shot_2020-06-23_at_12.50.12_PM.png">

- the connection that combines feature maps at the same level between the encoder and decoder

#### stacked hourglass

1. Make a prediction
2. Refine the prediction
3. Final prediction

- Intermediate supervision

<img src="https://curt-park.github.io/images/stacked_hourglass_networks/fig4-right.png">

- blue box: prediction -> loss function is computed (compute the prediction is good or not)
- calculate the each module's loss and use it when decoding
- each modules predicts joints
